items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Little Alne river gauge as a result of expected heavy rainfall over Sunday evening.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 21:00 today, 12/03/23.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Arrow between Studley and Salford Priors and the River Alne between Bird in Hand and Alcester on the River Alne including farmland and caravan parks.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high into Monday morning 13/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels are rising and forecast to continue rising at the Torksey river gauge as a result of snowmelt and forecast rainfall overnight tonight and tomorrow, 13/03/2023. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 12:00 tomorrow, 13/03/2023.  Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point, and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. However, further rainfall is forecast over the next few days.  We expect river levels to remain high until 14/03/2023.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our field team staff are closing pointing doors at Torksey tomorrow, around 12:00, 13/03/2023.
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 9:45 tomorrow morning, 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Warwick river gauge as a result of expected rainfall over Sunday evening.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Avon between Rugby and Bidford including Warwick, Stratford upon Avon, caravan parks and farmland.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high throughout Monday 13/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are falling at the Dernford river gauge. Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing. Flooding is affecting River Cam from Stapleford to Waterbeach.

Further rain is forecast for the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high and forecast to rise further at the Pillings Lock river gauge.  Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. Consequently, flooding is expected to continue.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road and Sileby Mill road, and farmlands at Cossington, Sileby, Barrow, Quorndon and Cotes. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River levels are rising on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water due to heavy rainfall overnight.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water.
No property flooding is expected.
River levels are expected to remain high for the rest of today, Monday 13th March.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising on the Rivers Kent and Bela due to heavy rainfall overnight.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Rivers Kent and Bela, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Rivers Kent and Bela and other watercourses, from Kentmere to Silverdale including low lying areas around Staveley, Burneside, Kendal, Milnthorpe and Beetham.
No property flooding is expected.
River levels are expected to remain high for the rest of today, Monday 13th March.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Erewash in Derbyshire and Nottinghamshire
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Shipley Gate river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 01:00 tomorrow morning, 13/03/23.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads around Pinxton, including the Pinxton Wharf access road, Langley Mill, Ilkeston, Stapleford, and the recreation area at Sandiacre.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until later tomorrow afternoon, 13/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are rising on the River Cherwell as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and farmland is expected, especially in the Thrupp area. 
The forecast this evening and overnight is for outbreaks of rain, which may be heavy at times. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are in the area clearing weed/trash screens. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall on the River Wey as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of footpaths and farmland is possible over today 12/03/23, especially in the Godalming and Bordon areas. Levels started to rise earlier in the week due to the heavy rainfall after a drier period and are expected to continue to respond to the showers particularly on the Hell Ditch. 
Further heavy rainfall is forecast in the early evening. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of snowmelt and rainfall.  Consequently, flooding is expected to continue.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood. Predicted peaks:-  Llanymynech 4.2m to 4.6m 13/03 overnight; and Cae Howel 5.2m to 5.7m 14/03 overnight.   
We expect river levels to remain high for several days.  Further rainfall is expected tonight, 12/03/23, and on Monday, 13/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 on 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Titley Mill river gauge as a result of recent rainfall and snowmelt.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to begin ovenight tonight, 12/03/23.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Arrow from Michaelchurch to Brierley. Other areas that may be affected include Kington, Staunton and Eardisland.   
Further rainfall is forecast overnight tonight and into Monday.
We expect river levels to remain high for the next 5 days.   
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated  by 08:00 on 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck

items.message:
River levels are rising on the Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck due to heavy rainfall overnight.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck and other watercourses, from Coniston to Barrow-in-Furness including low lying areas around Ulpha, Duddon Bridge, Broughton in Furness, Kirkby-in-Furness, Dalton in Furness and Ulverston.
No property flooding is expected.
River levels are expected to remain high for the rest of today, Monday 13th March.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.
Further rain is forecast later today, Sunday, and Monday which may cause the river levels to rise again.      
We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible from 5am Monday 13th March.

Heavy rain in the East Devon area has meant that the Rivers Clyst and Culm are now rising.

Flooding to low lying land and roads close to local rivers from around 5am on Monday is possible.

We expect river levels to remain high overnight and into the morning. Although no flooding to properties is currently forecast, we will monitor and issue any warnings if necessary.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.

We are constantly monitoring river levels and will update this message on Monday morning.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Cheswick Green river gauge as a result of expected rainfall over Sunday evening.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Blythe between Cheswick Green and Blyth End.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high throughout Monday 13/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising on the Rivers Lowther and Eamont due to heavy rainfall overnight.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Rivers Lowther and Eamont, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Rivers Eamont and Lowther to their confluence with the River Eden at Langwathby.
No property flooding is expected.
River levels are expected to remain high for the rest of today, Monday 13th March.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Crew Green river gauge as a result of recent rainfall & snowmelt.  Consequently, flooding of roads & farmland is expected to begin overnight tonight, 12/03/23.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land & roads adjacent the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are White Abbey, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge & Bridgnorth. River Severn bankfull at White Abbey. Predicted Peaks:- Crew Green 6.1m to 6.5m on 14/03/23, Montford 6m to 6.4m 14/03/23 overnight, Welshbridge 4m to 4.4m 15/03/23, Buildwas 5.3m to 5.7m 16/03/23, Bridgnorth 4.2m to 4.7m 16/03/23.
Further rainfall is forecast overnight & on Monday.
We expect river levels to remain high for the next 5 days
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses & plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded
This message will be updated  by 09:00 on 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise on the River Calder due to rainfall this evening, Sunday 12/03/2023, and overnight. River levels will be highest between 00:00 and 10:00 on Monday 13/03/2023. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Calder, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around River Calder from Brighouse to Castleford including Chickenley Beck, Spring Mill Beck and Wain Dike. No property flooding is currently expected. Further rainfall tomorrow is expected to increase river levels again tomorrow afternoon, peaking at approximately 22:00 on 13/03/2023. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.  This message will be updated by 09:00 on 13/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from early tomorrow morning, 13/03/2023.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.   
Further rainfall is forecast for tonight, 12/03/23 and Monday morning, 13/03/23. We expect river levels to remain high for about 5 days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 on 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising on the Upper River Eden due to heavy rainfall overnight.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper River Eden, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around River Eden and other watercourses, from Kirkby Stephen to Temple Sowerby including low lying areas around Brough, Warcop, Great Ormside and Appleby.
No property flooding is expected.
River levels are expected to remain high for the rest of today, Monday 13th March.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

River levels have risen and forecast to continue rising at the Whitewater Bridge river gauge as a result of snowmelt and forecast rainfall overnight tonight and tomorrow, 13/03/2023. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 4:00 tomorrow, 13/03/2023.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads around Mansfield, the Sherwood Forest Caravan Park at Clipstone, Edwinstowe, Ollerton, Whitewater Lane at Whitewater Bridge and West Drayton.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point, and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. However, further rainfall is forecast over the next few days.  
We expect river levels to remain high until 14/03/2023. We are closely monitoring the situation.   Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 09:45 tomorrow morning, 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise again at the Eathorpe river gauge as a result of expected rainfall overnight into Monday morning.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leam between Grandborough and Leamington including Kites Hardwick, Birdingbury, Marton, Eathorpe, Hunningham and Offchurch and the River Itchen between Southam and Marton including Long Itchington.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high into Monday morning, 13/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the River Ray as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and farmland is possible, especially in the Lower Arncott and Islip areas. 
The forecast this evening and overnight is for outbreaks of rain, which may be heavy at times. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are in the area clearing weed/trash screens. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Hay-On-Wye river gauge as a result of recent rainfall & snowmelt. Consequently, flooding of roads & farmland is expected to begin tomorrow morning, 13/03/23.
We expect flooding to affect low lying land & roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye
Other locations that may be affected include the A438, Byford, Bredwardine & Hereford. Predicted peaks:- Hay on Wye 2.6m to 3.1m overnight 13/03/23, Bredwardine 4.6m to 5.1m overnight 13/03/23, Belmont 4.7m to 5.2m 14/03/23, Old Wye Bridge 4m to 4.5m 14/03/23, Mordiford 4.5m to 4.9m 14/03/23, Ross on Wye 3.5m to 4m 14/03/23
Further rainfall is forecast overnight & on Monday
We expect river levels to remain high for the next 5 days
We are closely monitoring the situation
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses & plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded
This message will be updated by 09:00 on 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Cambridgeshire, North Northamptonshire, Peterborough, West Northamptonshire

items.message: Over the last few days, we have seen heavy rainfall and snow in the River Nene area. This means that the River Nene has risen, which has led to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. Although river levels have receded, we expect the river levels to rise again with further forecast rainfall later today, 12th March 2023, and the next few days. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outbuildings is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 09:00 on 13/03/23, or before if the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the River Thame and Chalgrove Brook as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and farmland is expected, especially in the Thame area.
The forecast this evening and overnight is for outbreaks of rain, which may be heavy at times.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are in the area clearing weed/trash screens. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall on the River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle due to rainfall.
Areas most at risk include the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole.
No property flooding is expected. Further light rainfall is forecast throughout the evening and through Sunday 12/03/23.
No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.
River levels are expected to remain high.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 03:00 PM on 11/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Bishops Frome river gauge as a result of recent rainfall and snowmelt.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible to begin tomorrow morning, 13/03/23.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Frome from Bromyard to Hereford. Other locations that may be affected include Bishops Frome and Yarkhill.   
Further rainfall is forecast overnight and into Monday.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 09:00 on 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Sutton Gault, Earith and Welney river gauges due to rainfall in the upper catchment. Flooding of roads and farmland is expected today, Sunday 12 March and is likely to continue into the week.

UPDATE - this flood alert now includes Welney causeway.

This information is correct as of 22:30 on Sunday 12 March. River levels are rising at Welney and are now at trigger level. Welney causeway currently has 0 cm of water on the road. However, we expect the water level to continue to rise through the night. Earith has approximately 20 cm of water on the road and the causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 46 cm of water on the road. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.

We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with Cambridgeshire and Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the roads
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated before 08:00 tomorrow morning, 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Shardlow and Willington river gauges. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected from 01:00 tomorrow morning, 13/03/23.   Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until at least Wednesday, 15/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Teme, River Onny and River Corve and their tributaries. Locations that may be affected include Bishops Castle, Church Stretton, Knighton and Ludlow. items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Strat, River Neet, River Ottery, River Kensey

items.message:
Flooding is possible from 1am on Monday 13th March and through the morning.

Light but persistent rainfall this afternoon has meant that the River Tamar is now rising, with a heavier band of rain forecast for the early hours of Monday morning.  This rainfall is forecast to clear during Monday morning, however the risk of further showers remains.

This may result in flooding to low lying land and roads close to the rivers. We expect river levels to remain high throughout this period, though no flooding to properties is currently expected.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and will update this message by 11am on Monday or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message:

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels are high but steady on Sunday the 12th March 2022 at the Bradford on Avon river gauge as a result of the recent heavy rainfall. We expect the River Avon to remain high for the next coming days; its possible there will be some flooding to affect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.   

The weather forecast for late Sunday and into Monday suggests some large rainfall totals. We will continue to closely monitor the situation.   

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  This message will be updated on the 13 March 2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Hookagate river gauge as a result of recent rainfall and snowmelt.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected from this afternoon, 12/03/23.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Shrewsbury to Church Stretton. Other locations that may be affected include Minsterley, Pontesford and Harrington. The floodplain has started to fill adjacent to the gauge on the left bank.   
Further rainfall is forecast for Sunday evening into Monday.
We expect river levels to remain high for the next 5 days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.
  
This message will be updated by 08:00 on 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Cae Howel river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from this morning onwards, 13/03/23.  We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in and around Melverley including Melverley to Melverley Green and Ponthen to Melverley roads.   
We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.    
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

This alert has been issued due to expected rising levels on the River Ure following snowmelt on Sunday, 12th March 2023 and rainfall expected during the night. The areas most at risk are low lying roads, paths and farmland near watercourses. Flooding of these areas near Low Houses and Bainbridge is possible from about 01:30 on Monday morning, 13th March 2023. Please exercise caution around low lying areas and put any relevant flood plans into action. Further rain is expected over the next day. We will continue to monitor the forecast and river levels and will update this message by 09:00 on Monday morning or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: Heavy rain and snow that fell across the River Nene catchment over the last few days has caused the River Nene levels to rise, and further rainfall is expected tonight. During periods of high tide the River Nene will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions. This is likely to lead to localised flooding of the North Bank Road, between Peterborough and Rings End. Whilst this Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. This Flood Warning is expected to be in place for a few days, whilst river and tide levels remain high. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 09:00 on 13/03/23, or before, if the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
Waves may potentially overtop sea defences in locations along the west coast of Dorset with sea spray expected as a result of high tides and strong winds.  Forecast high water is 09:00 on 13/03/23 with a Force 6 southwesterly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Weymouth, for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  Flooding may potentially affect Castletown, Weymouth, Preston Beach, Swanage Bay, Studland Bay, Sandbanks, Poole Harbour, Bournemouth Beach, Hengistbury Head and Christchurch Harbour   
Low pressure and high winds will cause sea levels to be higher than forecast in tide tables.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads.  
This message will be updated tomorrow, 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

Waves may potentially overtop sea defences in locations along the west coast of Dorset with sea spray expected as a result of high tides and strong winds.  Forecast high water is 11:00 on 13/03/23 with a Force 6 southwesterly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Portland, for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  Flooding may potentially affect Lyme Regis, Charmouth, Seatown, West Bay, Bothenhampton, Burton Freshwater, Burton Bradstock, Cogdean Beach, Chesil Beach, West Fleet, East Fleet and Chiswell   
Low pressure and high winds will cause sea levels to be higher than forecast in tide tables.

Over the last few days, we have seen heavy rainfall and snow in the Harpers Brook and Willow Brook area. This means that Harpers Brook and Willow Brook have risen, which has led to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outbuildings is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. But further rainfall is forecast for later on Sunday 12th March 2023 and over the next few days. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 09:00 on 13/03/23, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: The River Stour from Sudbury to Stratford St Mary and Dedham
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Sunday 12 March. River levels are currently high, but are expected to start to drop back down to more normal levels today. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas of the River Stour between Sudbury and Dedham. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for some rain expected overnight and the next few days are likely to be unsettled. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am Monday 13 March or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Colne from Great Yeldham to Colchester
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Sunday 12 March. We are currently seeing higher river levels than normal in the area. Areas most at risk are low lying land and riverside areas around Great Yeldham, Castle Hedingham, Sible Hedingham, Halstead, White Colne, Chappel, Fordstreet, and the Toppesfield Brook, and in Colchester between the A12 and East Street. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for some rain expected overnight and the next few days are likely to be unsettled. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am Monday 13 March or as the situation changes.

This means that the River Nene has risen, which has led to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outbuildings is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. But further rainfall is forecast for later on Sunday 12th March 2023 and over the next few days. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. items.message:
River levels along the Upper River Calder between Todmorden and Brighouse are forecast to rise later today in response to rainfall this evening. River levels will peak along the river between 2300 hours on 12/03/23 and 0400 hours on 13/03/23 but flooding of property is not expected. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.  This message will be updated by 09:00 on 13/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

No flood warnings are anticipated. This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 13/03/2023.

All times are local and refer to the high water time at West Bay, for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  We expect flooding to affect Esplanade, Quayside, Heron Court, Forty Foot Way, Driftwood, George Street, Swains Row, The Old Timberyard, Station Way, Pier Terrace and East Beach in West Bay 
Coastal conditions are expected to continue until after the high tides at 09:45 on 13/03/23 at West Bay.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads as large waves could be dangerous.  
This message will be updated 13/03/23 or as the situation changes.
